content: Definition of digestion
Introduction to the organs of the digestive system (mouth, oesophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, anus)
outcomes: Describe digestion.
Identify the organs of the digestive system.

topic: The Human Body: Digestive Process and Fate of Food
content: Detailed study of the functions of the organs of the digestive system
Absorption in the alimentary canal (focus on small intestine)
Fate of undigested food (e.g., formation and egestion of faeces)
outcomes: Identify the organs of the digestive system.
Identify parts of the alimentary canal where digested food is absorbed.
Explain what happens to undigested food.

content: Distinction between a virus and a bacterium (size, structure, reproduction)
Effect of viruses and bacteria on health (e.g., common cold, flu, cholera, tuberculosis)
outcomes: Distinguish between a virus and a bacterium.
Explain how viruses and bacteria can affect health.

topic: Health: Common Diseases and Health Services
content: Identification of common diseases of the skin (e.g., ringworm, scabies, rashes, boils)
Discussion on disease prevalence in relation to the provision of health services in Zambia (e.g., access to clinics, clean water, sanitation)
outcomes: Identify common diseases of the skin.
Explain the prevalence of diseases in relation to the provision of health services.

topic: Health: Nutritional Value of Fruits and Seeds (Part 1)
content: Identification of various fruits used as food (local Zambian fruits and common international fruits)
Identification of various seeds used as food (e.g., maize, groundnuts, beans, sunflower seeds)
outcomes: Identify fruits used as food.
Identify seeds used as food.

topic: Health: Nutritional Value of Fruits and Seeds (Part 2)
content: State the importance of fruits in improving health (e.g., rich in vitamins, minerals, fibre, boosting immunity)
State the importance of seeds in improving health (e.g., source of proteins, healthy fats, energy)
outcomes: State the importance of fruits in improving health.
State the importance of seeds in improving health.

content: Demonstration and practical activity: Separation of an insoluble solid from water (e.g., sand/soil from water using decantation and filtration)
Demonstration and practical activity: Separation of a soluble substance from water (e.g., salt/sugar solution by evaporation)
outcomes: Demonstrate the separation of an insoluble solid from water.
Demonstrate the separation of a soluble substance from water.

topic: The Environment: Separation Techniques (Part 2) and Water Sources
content: Demonstration and practical activity: Separation of iron filings from sand (using a magnet)
Identification of various sources of water in villages and towns (e.g., rivers, lakes, wells, boreholes, communal taps, piped water)
outcomes: Demonstrate the separation of iron fillings from sand.
Identify sources of water in the village and towns.

topic: The Environment: Water Treatment and Importance
content: Identification of different types of water treatment systems (e.g., boiling, chlorination, filtration, sedimentation, community water treatment plants)
State the importance of water treatment for public health and preventing waterborne diseases (e.g., cholera, dysentery)
outcomes: Identify different types of water treatment systems.
State the importance of water treatment.

content: Description of various ways of conserving water in homes, schools, and communities (e.g., rainwater harvesting, fixing leaky taps, using water sparingly, drip irrigation)
outcomes: Describe ways of conserving water.

topic: Plants and Animals: Parts of a Flower
content: Identification of the main parts of a typical flower (e.g., sepals, petals, stamens (anther and filament), carpel/pistil (stigma, style, ovary))
Practical observation and drawing of a suitable local flower specimen
outcomes: Identify the parts of a flower.

topic: Plants and Animals: Functions of Flower Parts
content: Explanation of the specific functions of each part of the flower (e.g., petals for attraction, stamens for pollen production, carpel for ovule protection and seed development)
Discussion on the role of flowers in plant reproduction
outcomes: Explain the functions of the parts of the flower.

content: Comprehensive review of all topics covered in Term 1: The Human Body, Health, The Environment, and Plants and Animals.
Practice exercises and past questions to prepare for termly examinations.
Formal written assessments and practical assessments where applicable.
outcomes: Consolidate understanding of all Term 1 Science topics.
Demonstrate knowledge and skills acquired through various assessment methods.
